thread.title: Brexit deal date revealed by Secretary Dominic Raab - and it's less than a month away

author: Daniel Milligan
title: Brexit deal date revealed by Secretary Dominic Raab - and it's less than a month away
text:
Creepiest things found in our sewers
Chancellor Philip Hammond delivered his last Budget on Monday saying the "era of austerity is finally coming to an end" - but we'll have to wait until next year before the Government reveals what that really means.
It is unclear when any such agreement would be made with the EU as there is, as yet, no EU summit planned for that time.
The vote for Brexit has already cost the average British worker more than £1,100 in lost wages, campaigners for a second referendum have claimed.
The People's Vote campaign seized on earnings growth figures released by the Office for Budget Responsibility alongside Chancellor Philip Hammond's Budget on Tuesday.
Leading supporter Chuka Umunna said the OBR's report showed that the average weekly pay packet is £11 smaller than had been expected before the referendum on June 23 2016. Labour politician Chuka Umunna (Image: Jack Taylor/Getty Images)
According to the official forecaster, by the end of 2018, earnings will have risen more slowly each year than was predicted ahead of the referendum.
In March 2016, the OBR's last pre-referendum forecast put average earnings growth at 2.6% for 2016, 3.6% in 2017 and 3.5% in 2018.
The independent experts say earnings grew by 2.7% in 2017 and are expected to rise by 2.6% this year.
The People's Vote calculated that the figures mean the average annual wage, which stood at £23,972 at the end of 2015, will reach just £25,792 by the end of this year, compared with the pre-referendum forecast of £26,364.
This means the average worker losing out by a total of £1,144 - made up of £208 in 2016, £364 in 2017 and £572 in 2018. Read More
